acf.name: Dr. Rahul
acf.payoff: I am a Medical Oncologist within the Division of Hematology/Oncology at the University of California San Francisco. My clinical practice focuses on patients with advanced solid tumor malignancies with a particular emphasis on genitourinary malignancies, including prostate, kidney, bladder, and testicular cancer. I serve as the Co-Leader for the GU Medical Oncology program at UCSF.
acf.text:
Dr. Rahul Aggarwal is a distinguished medical oncologist specializing in cancers of the genital and urinary organs at the University of California, San Francisco (UCSF) Helen Diller Family Comprehensive Cancer Center. He serves as the Associate Director for Clinical Sciences at the center and is an Associate Professor of Hematology/Oncology.

Dr. Aggarwal directs the UCSF STAND (Supportive Therapy in Androgen Deprivation) Clinic, where he provides comprehensive care to patients receiving androgen deprivation therapy for prostate cancer. His research is focused on developing novel hormonal treatment strategies aimed at reducing the toxicity of androgen deprivation therapy for men with advanced prostate cancer.

He has been involved in numerous clinical trials, exploring new treatments for genitourinary cancers. Dr. Aggarwal completed his medical degree at the Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine and undertook his residency and fellowship in hematology and oncology at UCSF. Additionally, he has received the ASCO/Conquer Cancer Foundation Young Investigator Award for his contributions to cancer research.

acf.name: Dr. Ken
acf.role: Advisor and Interim Head of Medicinal Chemistry
acf.payoff: Kenneth G. Carson is a seasoned leader in the biotechnology industry with extensive experience spanning multiple roles and companies.
acf.text:
​He currently works at Peptone as an Advisor and the Interim Head of Medicinal Chemistry and is the Founder and Principal of KGC Biotech Consulting LLC, where he advises biotech clients on drug discovery, hit finding, and project progression.

Previously, he served as Executive Vice President of Chemical Sciences at HotSpot Therapeutics Inc. from 2019 to 2024, overseeing medicinal chemistry, DNA-encoded libraries (DEL), and the New Jersey site operations. ​ During his tenure, he successfully delivered active chemical matter for multiple targets.
​
Before HotSpot, Ken founded and led Macroceutics, Inc. as CEO from 2014 to 2019, focusing on building and screening DNA-encoded libraries, which eventually led to a merger with HotSpot Therapeutics. ​ His earlier career includes significant roles at Lexicon Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Millennium Pharmaceuticals, Inc., and LeukoSite Inc., where he led various drug discovery programs and managed large teams of scientists.
​
Ken holds a Ph.D. in Organic Chemistry from Cornell University, an M.S. ​ in Organic Chemistry from Bucknell University, and a B.S. ​ in Chemistry. He has contributed to numerous patents and publications, showcasing his expertise in drug discovery and development across various therapeutic areas, including immunology, oncology, and metabolic diseases. ​ His work has led to the progression of multiple compounds into clinical development and successful corporate partnerships. ​

acf.name: Dr. Babette
acf.text:
Babette has extensive knowledge in oncology, immunotherapy, cell biology and signal transduction with a high interest in translational science.

She obtained her master’s degree in biochemistry and her PhD in cell and molecular biology at the National Research Council Canada in Montreal with focus on stress response in yeast. During her post-doctoral research and research associate position in the Molecular Oncology Group at the Goodman Cancer Center in Montreal she investigated the role of ErbB2 and its coupled downstream signaling pathways in the development of breast cancer using ErbB2 transgenic mouse models.

Before Babette joined Peptone, she worked TargImmune Therapeutics as head of biology and was responsible for preclinical development to IND of Ta:RNAs (tumor-targeting nanoparticle platform), including development of in vitro and in vivo pharmacology studies, mode of action evaluation and biomarker identification.

Prior to this, she gained experience in biologic drug discovery and preclinical development of bi-specific antibodies at Covagen and Janssen Pharmaceuticals, leading and planning research strategies for immune-oncology programs, including translational research, biomarker discovery and respective assay development.

acf.name: Dr. Benjamin
acf.text:
Ben has over 25 years of experience of molecular modelling for drug discovery in academia and industry.

Ben joined Peptone from Exscientia where he was head of design development leading a team of teams focused on building, maintaining and using an automated 3D modelling and simulation platform for small molecule projects.

Before this Ben spend more than 10 years at UCB building and applying modelling technologies in challenging small molecule projects.

A particular focus was on evaluating challenging targets and applying novel virtual screening technologies.

A background in molecular simulation was gained with PhD at Southampton and a PostDoc at the Barcelona supercomputer centre.

acf.name: Prof. Marc
acf.payoff: Professor Marc Mansour is an honorary consultant haematologist at University College London Hospital and Great Ormond Street Children’s Charity professor of haematolgy at GOS ICH/UCL Cancer Institute.
acf.text:
He undertook his medical degree at the University of Edinburgh, medical training at King’s College London and UCLH, followed by an MRC clinical research training PhDship in the laboratory of Professors David Linch and Rosemary Gale at UCL, where he studied notch signalling in acute leukaemia.

He was funded by the Kay Kendell Leukemia Research Fund to undertake a travelling fellowship at Harvard Medical School and Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston, USA. He was awarded the HMS Claudia Adams Barr Innovative Research award, and was a Harvard Medical School faculty member from 2012-2014. He was funded through a Bennett senior fellowship (Blood Cancer UK) to establish his own research lab at the UCL Cancer Institute in 2014.

His research has focused on two aggressive haematological malignancies – T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (T-ALL) and acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). He has published extensively on the biology of acute leukaemia, authoring papers in Science, Nature, Nature Cell Biology, JCI, ELife, JCO and J Ex Med. His clinical interest is in ALL, AML and myelodysplasia (MDS).

acf.name: Prof. Andrea
acf.payoff: Prof. Andrea Alimonti is the Director of the Institute of Oncology Research (IOR), where he is also head of the Molecular Oncology Group. He is full professor at Università della Svizzera italiana and ETH Zurich.
acf.text:
Prof. Alimonti received his MD degree from the University of Rome “La Sapienza” and his medical and training in oncology from the National Cancer Institute of Rome. He completed a postdoctoral fellowship in cancer biology first at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York and then at Harvard Medical School in Boston. In 2010 he joined the IOR, as head of the Molecular Oncology Group and in January 2024 he was appointed the new IOR Director. During his career, he has obtained important awards and competitive grants (EMBO Young Investigator, Swiss Bridge Award, ERC Starting, Consolidator and Advanced Grants, J. Steiner Cancer Research Award, Prostate Cancer Foundation Award, Award from the Benioff Initiative for Prostate Cancer Research). He is the author of many clinical and basic research publications in major scientific journals (e.g. Science, Nature, Cell, Nat. Gen etc).

The major scientific contributions of Prof. Alimonti’s research include the discovery of a therapeutic approach based on the induction of cellular senescence and immune response against the tumor; the identification of an immune cell type, the myeloid-derived suppressor cells, that can promote prostate cancer progression and resistance to standard therapies; the identification of a novel mechanism of therapy resistance in prostate cancer involving the gut microbiota. Prof. Alimonti’s vision is to develop state-of-the-art innovative treatments for patients affected by cancer. Some of these treatments are currently being tested in the clinic.

acf.name: Prof. Johann
acf.payoff: Professor Johann de Bono is the Head of the Division of Clinical Studies and an international expert in the development of novel anticancer therapies against adult cancers. His group of runs one of the world’s largest phase I clinical trials units for cancer, with >100 staff including dedicated radiology and pathology staff; he also runs a separate group focused on improving prostate cancer care that have led pivotal phase III trials of several prostate cancer drugs including abiraterone, cabazitaxel, enzalutamide and olaparib as well more recently ipatasertib and lutetium-PSMA.
acf.text:
Professor Johann de Bono is Regius Professor of Cancer Research and a Professor in Experimental Cancer Medicine at The Institute of Cancer Research and The Royal Marsden NHS Foundation Trust. He is also the Director of the Drug Development Unit, overseeing the conduct of phase I trials, with a particular interest in innovative trial designs, circulating biomarkers and prostate cancer. Additionally, he leads the Prostate Cancer Targeted Therapy Group and the Cancer Biomarkers group.

Education and training: He graduated from the University of Glasgow medical school in 1989,  as a Member of the Royal College of Physicians (MRCP) in 1992. He was awarded a four-year Cancer Research Campaign Clinical Fellowship, which allowed him to pursue a PhD between 1993–97. Following his PhD, he trained in medical oncology and was awarded an MSc (Cancer Sciences) from the University of Glasgow. The Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow then awarded him a travelling scholarship that allowed him to pursue further research on the challenges of clinical trial design at the SWOG statistical headquarters at the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Centre in Seattle, US, in 1999. Between 2000–03, he then pursued further research developing novel anti-cancer drugs at the Institute for Drug Development within the University of Texas Health Science Centre at San Antonio, Texas. He joined the Institute of Cancer Research, London, in 2003.

Honours and awards: Professor de Bono has received many other awards during his career including a Cancer Research Campaign PhD Clinical Research Fellowship, American Society of Clinical Oncology Merit and Young Investigator Awards, a Doris Duke Charitable Foundation Clinician-Scientist Award, and a Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow Travel Award. In 2003, Professor de Bono was elected a fellow of the Royal College of Physicians (London) and of the Royal College of Physicians and Surgeons of Glasgow. In 2009, he was elected as a Member of the Malta Order of Merit. He received the prestigious European Society for Medical Oncology (ESMO) Award in 2012 and was part of the ICR/Royal Marsden team awarded the American Association of Cancer Research (AACR) Team Science Award. He also received an award from the Royal Society of Chemistry for his group’s work in developing abiraterone, as well as the 2018 AACR – Joseph H. Burcheval Memorial Award for Outstanding Achievement in Clinical Cancer Research.

In July 2016 he was named as Regius Professor of Cancer Research – a rare award bestowed by the Sovereign by Royal Warrant to recognise exceptionally high-quality research at an institution, and the first such Professorship devoted to cancer.

Professor de Bono is also a key opinion leader in the development of novel cancer therapies, and co-founded and now runs The Royal Marsden Drug Development Unit, one of the world’s largest such trials units for cancer patients. He has been involved in the development of many novel agents, many of which are now approved drugs.

He is a world leader in prostate cancer research, having changed the treatment of prostate cancer multiple times through trials of the ICR-discovered drug abiraterone, cabazitaxel, enzalutamide and olaparib. He also led on the identification of germline and somatic DNA repair defects in lethal prostate cancer, and co-led studies mapping the genomics of these diseases. His work has changed international guidelines on germline testing in men with advanced prostate cancer and the first molecular stratification for this commonest of male cancers. He has also recently led studies of pembrolizumab, talazoparib, ipatasertib and lutetium-PSMA for men suffering from advanced prostate cancer.

His laboratory has led on the study of liquid biopsies in advanced prostate cancer including circulating tumour cells, whole blood expression profiling, and plasma circulating tumour DNA in metastatic prostate cancer patients. He helped to pioneer the concept of patient molecular stratification in early clinical trials through the Pharmacological Audit Trial.

As well as research, Professor de Bono is involved in training and supervising PhD and MD(Res) research students. He has published more than 500 scientifically peer-reviewed manuscripts in journals including The New England Journal of Medicine, The Lancet, Lancet Oncology, Nature, Nature Cancer Reviews, Journal of Clinical Oncology, Clinical Cancer Research and Cancer Research. He has held editorial roles at multiple peer-reviewed journals and was the Scientific Programme Chair of the ESMO annual meeting in 2014, the Clinical Program Co-Chair of the AACR Annual Meetings in 2015 and 2016, the UK National Cancer Research Institute (NCRI) Annual Meeting 2016 and 2017 Deputy Chair and Chair, the Prostate AACR 2017 meeting Scientific Chair, and the ESMO Targeted Anticancer Therapy (TAT) Scientific Programme Chair. He leads the ICR and The Royal Marsden Experimental Cancer Medicine Centre and the Movember London Prostate Cancer Centre of Excellence.

acf.name: Dr. Jonathan
acf.payoff: I am interested in how molecules move, how this underpins important biological functions and ultimately how we can direct those dynamics to create new opportunities for medicine and biosensing.
acf.text:
My background is in protein biophysics – developing physical and chemical methods to gain insight into molecular structure, folding and dynamics. I have experience in studying naturally occurring proteins and also in synthetic biology – designing and building protein switches and self-assembly systems. These dual skillsets were ultimately brought together to study and engineer protein drugs and drug targets.

The research in my lab is focused on three interwoven threads:

  1. Studying the assembly and dynamics of protein systems in nature.
  2. Creating new molecular systems for medicine and biosensing.
  3. Advancing analytical methods to better understand protein dynamics.

Broad research specialisms

Biochemistry
Protein biophysics
Analytical chemistry
Mass spectrometry

Interests:

I am interested in how molecules move, how this underpins important biological functions and ultimately how we can direct those dynamics to create new opportunities for medicine and biosensing.

My background is in protein biophysics – developing physical and chemical methods to gain insight into molecular structure, folding and dynamics. Much of this has been in what are termed ‘structural mass spectrometry’ techniques. The core approach used in my lab is hydrogen/deuterium-exchange mass spectrometry (HDX-MS), which is experiencing something of a renaissance: it has unique advantages in being able to measure protein structure, dynamics and thermodynamics (stability) in arbitrarily large systems (e.g. antibody dimers of 300 kDa), rapidly (<= seconds) and with single amino acid resolution. We are active in developing experimental and computational methods and tools to advance the scope of this powerful analytical technique.

I have experience in studying naturally occurring protein structure, folding and dynamics and also in synthetic biology – designing and building protein switches and self-assembly systems. These dual skillsets were first brought together in a biomedical context with an industrial fellowship to study and engineer protein drugs and drug targets. This momentum is continued at The Living Systems Institute as we investigate naturally occurring biological control and the potential to design conscious control of molecular systems.

acf.name: Prof. Kresten
acf.payoff: My research deals broadly with the relationship between protein structure, dynamics and function.
acf.text:
We mostly use computational methods, generally integrated very tightly with experimental studies, to understand how the ability of proteins to change their shape help modulate, or indeed determines, their function.

We have contributed to methods for integrating NMR spectroscopy and atomistic simulations to study the motions of both folded and intrinsically disordered proteins and more recently RNA. We have demonstrated how simulations can be used to elucidate slow motions in proteins and capture the mechanism, thermodynamics and kinetics of conformational change and ligand binding processes.  We were also the first to determine the structures of fibrillar proteins using sequence coevolution and NMR.

Within protein folding we have pushed the boundaries of how simulations can be used to study folding mechanisms. We have developed simulation methods and some of the most accurate force fields for simulations, that are now used by thousands of researchers worldwide. Together, these developments enabled us to provide unprecedented mechanistic insight and detail of the process of protein folding. More recently, we have shown how simpler models can be used to study the complexities of membrane protein folding , and how models of protein folding and evolution can be used to understand how diseases develop.

acf.name: Dr. Kevin
acf.text:
An entrepreneurial and energetic scientific drug hunter with a proven history of working collaboratively with inter-disciplinary scientists, business partners and investors to successfully advance companies and small molecule drug discovery programs from the earliest stages through to human clinical development, providing maximum value for patients and shareholders.

A people-first leader with a track record of building highly-engaged and high-performing teams.

With over 20 years of biotech and drug discovery experience, led or contributed to 10+ INDs and clinical-stage assets across 7+ companies, including Millennium, Ironwood/Microbia, Verastem Oncology, Syros Pharmaceuticals, Ventus/SMOC Therapeutics, Avilar Therapeutics and Stablix, Inc.

Earned Ph.D. in organic chemistry from the University of Kansas and completed post-doctoral work with E.J. Corey at Harvard University. Contributed to 35+ patents and provisional applications and 40+ manuscripts and presentations covering small molecule drug discoveries.

acf.name: Dr. Lixin
acf.text:
With a solid educational background in pharmaceutical sciences, Dr Yang holds a master’s degree in medicinal chemistry and is qualified in computer-aided drug design (CADD) from Peking University in Beijing.

Lixin enjoys identifying the right molecular partners for intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) using protein mass spectrometry (MS) and complementary biophysical tools. Driven by a curiosity about neurodegenerative diseases and challenging targets, he pursued a PhD at EPFL in Switzerland, focusing on studying protein aggregation in IDPs, such as TDP-43 and α-Synuclein (aSyn).

Additionally, Dr. Yang is interested in how protein engineering and chemical tools can be employed to stabilize the functional states of these proteins.

As a drug discovery enthusiast, he is eager to devote his career to the pharmaceutical industry, leveraging his diverse research skills. Protein stability, dynamics, aggregation, and pharmacological intervention with various molecular modalities are particularly fascinating to him.

He is now ready to tackle challenges using Peptone’s advanced protein analytical and biophysical techniques.

acf.name: Dr. Peter
acf.role: Non-Executive Director and Chairman of the Scientific Advisory Board
acf.text:
Dr. Kiener is an industry veteran with extensive experience in both biologics and immunotherapy, and biopharmaceutical research and drug development.

Previously, he was chief scientific officer at Sucampo, which was acquired by Mallinckrodt and served as chief scientific officer of Ambrx Inc., a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company focused on the development of antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs).

Dr. Kiener was also president and co-founder of Zyngenia Inc., an early-stage biopharmaceutical company and served as executive vice president and global head of biologics research and development at MedImmune LLC, the global biologics arm of AstraZeneca.

Dr Kiener has served as a member of the Board of Directors and Scientific Advisory Boards of several public and private biotechnology companies.

He received a Bachelor of Science from Lancaster University in Lancaster, UK and his DPhil in biochemistry from Oxford University, Sir William Dunn School of Pathology.

acf.name: Alex
acf.role: Business Development and Strategic Intelligence Manager
acf.text:
Business Development professional with extensive experience in the biopharmaceuticals industry.

I have managed a wide array of responsibilities, including identifying potential deals, coordinating due diligence for both in-licensing and out-licensing initiatives, and effectively managing partnerships and alliances in various capacities at BenevolentAI and Eisai.

During my tenure at Eisai, I played a pivotal role in facilitating the divestiture of a £100M marketed antiepileptic drug, from identifying potential buyers to deal closure. Subsequently, I led the post-transactional activities, managing cross-functional teams during the transition of the business to the acquirer.

Prior to that, I was part of the Venture Support Unit of Imperial Innovations (former Technology Transfer Office of Imperial College London), focusing on commercializing academic research and supporting the university’s spin-outs across a broad range of technology sectors and stages including formation, scale and financing.

I hold an MSc in Cellular Therapy from Bench to Market from King’s College London and an MSc in Biological Applications & Technologies from the University of Ioannina, Greece.

acf.name: Dr. Sasha
acf.role: Scientist 2 - Cell Biology and Functional Screenings
acf.text:
Dr. Sasha Soldati obtained a bachelor’s degree in Biology and a master’s degree in Molecular Life Sciences at the University of Bern, Switzerland, and a PhD in Immunology at the Theodor Kocher Institute, University of Bern, Switzerland. 

During his PhD studies, he mainly focused on studying immune-cell migration to the central nervous system in the context of neurovegetative diseases and was able to address important therapeutic questions in a collaborative project with the pharmaceutical company Biogen Idec to increase knowledge on the minimal dosing regimen and safety of Natalizumab, a monoclonal antibody for the treatment of multiple sclerosis. Furthermore, he has contributed to several academic research publications investigating the molecular mechanism of immune-cell adhesion and migration across the blood-brain brain and the blood-cerebrospinal fluid barrier by employing different models derived from iPSCs and state-of-art microfluidic devices.

Between his master’s and doctoral degrees, he gained additional technical experience in cell and molecular biology as research assistant at the University of Bern.

Dr. Sasha Soldati now works as a Scientist – Functional Screening and Bioassay Development – and is bringing his expertise in immunology to the intriguing world of intrinsically disordered proteins at Peptone Switzerland AG.

acf.name: Fahad
acf.text:
Fahad is a Chartered Certified Accountant, a full ACCA member since February 2020.

He was trained in the public practice environment for 10 years, where he worked with startups and scale-up businesses helping them with Tax, Accounts, Compliance, and setting up internal finance functions.

Fahad completed my Master’s in Business Administration from the University of Sunderland in November 2014.

He left the practice environment to work at AET UK Limited part of MISC/Petronas Group as their Finance Manager for the UK/EU region plus FP&A functions for Deep Positioning Shuttle Tankers operating across the EU and Brazil region.

In his last 10 years of experience, Fahad has worked on R&D claims for interesting start-ups from Tech backgrounds, also helping them set up SEIS and EIS schemes helping them raise funding from investors.

acf.name: Dr. Andrea
acf.text:
Andrea has over 25 years of experience in the genomics field and 15 years in logistics.

He obtained a BSc in molecular biology, a PhD and post-doctoral research in oncology and genetics. He also achieved a four-year specialization in medical genetics.

Founder of the Genomic Facility at BIOS+ in Bellinzona, he is our trusted navigator through logistic, scientific and technology-related waters.

Always open to a new challenge, he works as COO and head of the Genomic Facility at the Institute of Oncology Research.

In joining Peptone as a counsellor, Andrea is poised to leverage his expertise as a seasoned problem solver, bringing a logistical acumen to tackle challenges head-on.

acf.name: Dr. Thomas
acf.text:
I am an experienced medicinal chemist with an MChem from the University of York (2011) and a PhD from the University of Cambridge (2015) working on the synthesis and evaluation conjugated 6,6-ring systems with a bridgehead nitrogen as pharmaceutical isosteres. After my PhD, I undertook an industrial postdoc at AstraZeneca (UK) working on sp3 C-H activation methodology.

I began my industrial career in 2016 working at Sygnature Discovery Ltd (Nottingham, UK) for 5 years on an immunology project progressing both as a bench chemist and later as a team/project leader. I then moved to Mission Therapeutics Ltd (Cambridge, UK) in 2022 as a Principal Medicinal Chemist working on DUB (Deubiquinating enzyme) inhibitors before joining Peptone in 2024.

I have been involved with programs that have delivered multiple clinical candidates, I have authored or co-authored 6 peer-reviewed publications and named as an inventor on over 10 patent cases.

acf.name: Dr. Daniele
acf.text:
Daniele obtained his Master’s in Pharmaceutical Chemistry and Technology at the University of Padua (Italy) in 2015 and completed his Ph.D. in Molecular Sciences at the same institution in 2019. His doctoral research focused on uncovering novel thrombin interactions and exploring noncanonical pathways of prothrombin activation.

Following his Ph.D., Daniele joined Prof. John Engen’s laboratory as a Postdoctoral Research Associate at Northeastern University in Boston, where he specialized in performing HDX MS experiments, played a role in developing the HDX MS technique, and conducted research on amyloidogenic proteins and protein folding.

Now, as a senior scientist mass spectrometry at Peptone, Daniele continues to advance the HDX MS technique and contributes to the study of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) through HDX MS experiments.

acf.name: Rachel
acf.payoff: You’ll find me with my head in a spreadsheet but I also like to know what’s going on behind the numbers. Working in a small company means you get to know so much more than just the numbers & I love working in a scientific company having been a chemist myself!
acf.text:
Rachel was trained in Chemistry at the University of Bristol (MSc 2010) before becoming a chartered accountant (ACA 2013).
Initially starting out in audit, she moved into industry shortly after qualifying, with a specialism in the pharmaceutical industry.
Over 4 years at IQVIA (initially Quintiles), one of the largest CROs, gave her a good grounding knowledge of financial planning and analysis (FP&A) as well as how a clinical trial works, ending with her being responsible for the planning & reporting of a global business unit.
She then moved to Zogenix, a NASDAQ listed company specialising in rare disease, where she was only the second member of the European finance team in a total team of 15. She helped to grow both the finance team to 8 people and the whole of the EU company, from 2 entities initially to 6 entities across multiple EU countries with 49 employees.
The company obtained EMA approval whilst she was there, giving her experience from the regulatory process through to selling & she was the finance representative on the EU Fintepla brand performance team.
Being the finance manager in the team gave Rachel experience of all parts of finance from the statutory submissions of accounts, tax & VAT across the EU entities; through entity & transfer pricing set up to sales models & operational stock planning.
Known for her FP&A experience, as the company grew, she specialised once again in this area in 2021, helping to set up a US & UK team from scratch before UCB purchased Zogenix in 2022.

acf.text:
Matt trained in Molecular Genetics at the University of Sussex (BSc 2003) and in Tumour Immunology at the University of York (PhD 2012) with post-doctoral training at the University of Cambridge.

More recently, he’s spent over 8 years at F-star Therapeutics, a clinical-stage biotech specialising in bispecific antibody engineering, where he was Head of Immunology and Project Lead executing a Phase 1 study across Europe.

acf.name: Valentina
acf.role: Scientist 2 - Cell Biology and Functional Screenings
acf.payoff: I am driven by the belief that scientific excellence is key to developing novel strategies for therapeutic interventions.
acf.text:
I am a biologist, and I pursued my studies at the University of Milan, where I achieved an MSc in Biology Applied to Biomedical Research.

During my career, I developed a strong passion for applying innovative strategies to understand complex systems, such as brain tumours, cerebrovascular disorders, spinal diseases and prostate cancer.

My expertise comprises the production of autologous cell-based vaccines, generation and engineering of patient-derived cell lines, setup of 3D and organoid systems, optimization of multiple in vitro functional assays and drug-screening methods.

I am extremely fascinated by the concept that a rigorous scientific approach, combined with curiosity, allows for unravelling clinically relevant information.

acf.name: Dr. Andrew
acf.text:
Board chair Dr. Allen has served as co-founder, President and CEO of Gritstone bio since 2015. He was also co-founder of Clovis Oncology where he served as Chief Medical Officer until 2015, overseeing the development of rucaparib, an approved PARP inhibitor.

Prior to that, Dr. Allen was Chief Medical Officer at Pharmion Corporation, acquired by Celgene in 2008, where he led the development of Vidaza, the first approved DNA methylation inhibitor. He has also held clinical development leadership positions at Chiron Corporation and Abbott Laboratories and worked at McKinsey & Company.

Currently, Dr. Allen serves on the board of directors of several public and private biopharma companies. He graduated in Medicine from Oxford University and received a PhD in immunology from the Imperial College of Science, Technology, and Medicine in London.

acf.name: Dr. David
acf.text:
David has been discovering and developing biologic therapeutics for over 25 years. Having gained his PhD from the University of Cambridge, in 1997 he joined Cambridge Antibody Technology, (CAT) the pioneering seat-up company that invented phage display of antibodies. Following the acquisition of CAT by AstraZeneca, David spent many years both developing antibody and protein engineering technology platforms, alongside leading the discovery and preclinical development of many different biologic modalities, from antibodies and antibody-like molecules, peptides and recombinant proteins, through to mRNA and AAV gene therapies.

Outside of science, most of his time is spent trying to keep up with his three children!

acf.name: Dr. Patrik
acf.payoff: Peptone is addressing an important drug design challenge through a bespoke use of HDX-MS and generative AI and at a time when our understanding of the biology is being propelled by advances in structural biochemistry techniques, such as CryoEM.
acf.text:
Patrik is an experienced scientific leader with more than 20 years’ experience in pharma and biotech successfully transitioning programs into the clinic in multiple therapeutic areas including inflammation, neuroscience. Patrik joins from Sitryx Therapeutics where he was SVP Pre-clinical Drug Discovery overseeing the internal and external pre-clinical activities from target ID up to IND. He was instrumental building the pre-clinical pipeline at Sitryx, establishing and managing the strategic alliance with Eli Lilly and Company.

Prior to this Patrik was Head of Immuno-Bone Discovery at UCB Pharma, responsible for small molecule and antibody projects from target identification to clinical proof of concept. Previously, he was managing the molecular and cellular biology, primary pharmacology and screening departments in a range of disease areas including immunology, bone, and neurology. He has successfully led several large and small molecule drug discovery programs in a variety of disease indications and with several external partners. Patrik was instrumental in multiple Public Private Partnerships (IMI, Neuroallianz).

Patrik has a diploma in biology and received a PhD in molecular biology from EMBL Heidelberg and has published over two dozen peer-reviewed publications.

acf.name: Dr. Anastasiya
acf.payoff: Anastasiya is an Associate with F-Prime Capital’s London team, focusing on healthcare investments.
acf.text:
Anastasiya is an Associate with F-Prime Capital in London, focusing on healthcare investments. She is a Board Observer on Peptone, as well as two other F-Prime portfolio companies in the fields of cellular rejuvenation and immuno-oncology.

Prior to joining F-Prime, Ana was an Engagement Manager at McKinsey specializing in Pharmaceuticals & Medical Products and had previously worked as a Strategy Consultant at Advancy.

Ana holds a Ph.D. in Stem Cell Biology and Medicine from the University of Cambridge (UK), a MSc in Molecular and Cell Biology from École normale supérieure (Paris, France) and a BSc in Biology from Ivan Franko National University of Lviv (Ukraine).

acf.name: Dr. Sandro
acf.payoff: My research focuses on developing physics-based molecular models of proteins and nucleic acids, and their integration with biophysical experiments.
acf.text:
Dr. Sandro Bottaro has a background in theoretical physics and ten years of experience in the field of computational biology. His research focuses on developing physics-based molecular models of proteins and nucleic acids, and their integration with biophysical experiments.

During his scientific pilgrimages at different European research institutes, Sandro has learned how chemistry, bioinformatics, and machine learning can be effectively combined together to tackle fundamental biological problems.

This combination is ideally suited for characterizing disordered and flexible biomolecules such as IDPs, for which neither simulations nor experiments alone can currently provide atomic-detailed structural information.

acf.name: Fabio
acf.role: Head of Software and Data Engineering
acf.payoff: I am fascinated with all things computer-related.
acf.text:
After obtaining a master degree in computer engineering at Politecnico di Milano with a thesis on hybrid recommendation systems in 2011, Fabio started his career at Moviri as an application performance and data center capacity planning consultant. In 2014 he moved to Boston to help expand Moviri’s presence in the United States.

Fabio moved back to Italy in 2019, were he joined Empatica, an MIT spin-off focused on wearable devices for monitoring patients with neurological conditions, where he was instrumental in modernizing and securing the IT infrastructure, and optimizing the data processing pipeline.

In 2020 he joined Sysdig, a DevSecOps startup, where he collaborated with multiple software development teams to redesign critical parts of the product in order to massively increase performance and scalability. He also helped expanding the European site reliability engineering team and kickstarting a team in APAC.

acf.name: Chiara
acf.payoff: I am continuously seeking for new challenges in the pharmaceutical field.
acf.text:
Born in Switzerland in 1992, I pursued all my studies in Italy, and completed my courses at Università Degli Studi di Pavia, with a bachelor’s degree in medical and pharmaceutical biotechnology.

I worked for several years in the pharmaceutical field in Switzerland as a microbiologist technician in a quality control group, and after that, I experienced the research side firsthand by working at the Institute of Research in Biomedicine (IRB) in Bellinzona on different projects.

acf.name: Dr. Gabriella
acf.payoff: I’m very excited to join Peptone as Associate Biosafety Officer as I’m always looking for new projects that allow me to expand my knowledge and offer me new challenges!
acf.text:
I was born in Italy where I graduated in Biology at the University of Varese. I then moved to Germany
where I got my PhD in Neuroendocrinology at the University of Magdeburg.

After moving to Switzerland, I joined the Institute for Research in Biomedicine (IRB) in Bellinzona where I have been working for several years as vice-Biosafety Officer. My duties and responsibilities include organizing a Biosafety Concept Introduction for all new employees, regular Biosafety-specific updates for groups in relation to their work as well as periodic inspections in all IRB premises.

At Peptone, I assist group leaders in performing risk assessments for activities involving hazardous biological agents and genetically modified organisms and register and update all federal notifications and authorizations. As a Biosafety professional, I believe that my most important task is to promote and enhance a strong safety culture at the workplace.

acf.name: Dr. Elia
acf.payoff: I want to share my expertise with Peptone helping to rationalize failures in drug development to inform the design of future drugs.
acf.text:
I have an MSc in Medicinal Chemistry from the University of Padova, focusing on biologic drugs including protein and nucleic acids therapeutics

After my degree, I obtained a PhD from the University of Padova where I worked on small molecules targeting the interaction between the HIV-1 nucleocapsid protein and its nucleic acid substrates as potential novel antiretroviral agents. There, I have used a combination of spectrophotometric, electrophoretic and mass spectrometry techniques to screen compound libraries and elucidate the mechanism of action of the hits.

I later pursued a career in the bio-pharma industry as a formulation development scientist for protein therapeutics, where I gained a strong expertise in protein stability and developability of novel biological entities, and an extensive experience with most analytical methods for protein characterization.

acf.name: Dr. Francis
acf.payoff: I’m especially passionate about the spectacular convergence between deep, foundational disciplines that used to be unconnected, such as biology + computer science + semiconductors, or quantum physics + computer science. In the pursuit of these passions, I’m keen to work  with visionary founders who invent new paths to reach previously impossible destinations.
acf.text:
Francis is a partner at Walden Catalyst Ventures. Francis’s passion for science and mathematics led him to a 13-year career in venture capital, complemented by deep operating experience with two IPOs and one M&A exit. Prior to Walden Catalyst, he served as Co-Head of Samsung Catalyst Fund, bringing innovation to scale.

His experience across deep tech, AI, cloud, and digital biology includes roles at Inphi, McKinsey, JP Morgan Partners, and ONI Systems. A student of new technologies and innovations, he holds seven U.S. patents for semiconductor and storage technologies. Francis attended Caltech (BS physics, MS applied physics) and Stanford (PhD physics, postdoc quantum optics).

acf.name: Dr. Alex
acf.payoff: Dr. Alex Pasteur is a Partner with F-Prime Capital. Alex has worked in  healthcare investing since 2001 and is based in London.
acf.text: Alex focuses on investments in therapeutics and healthcare IT.  His portfolio includes/included Nodthera Ltd, Oviva AG, Owkin Inc., Genomics PLC, Castor (Ciwit BV), Pulmocide Ltd, Arvelle Therapeutics (acquired by Angelini Pharma), Orchard Therapeutics (NASDAQ: ORTX), Acacia Pharma (BRU: ACPH) and Adaptimmune Therapeutics (NASDAQ: ADAP).  Prior to joining F-Prime in 2012, Alex worked at MVM Life Science Partners LLP in the USA and Europe. Alex earned a M.A. in Natural Sciences from Cambridge University and a Ph.D. in Chemistry from Cambridge University.

acf.name: Andrew
acf.payoff: “The world needs tenacious healthcare founders now more than ever. Patients’ lives will be permanently better off because these teams are just crazy enough to be up for the task.”
acf.text:
Andrew Hedin is a partner in Bessemer’s Cambridge, MA office where he focuses on investments broadly across the healthcare ecosystem, including new biotech therapeutics as well as software and services sold to healthcare verticals.

Prior to joining Bessemer in 2015, Andrew worked at F-Prime Capital, Fidelity’s healthcare-focused venture capital fund where he invested in early-stage biotech and digital health technologies, as well as Leerink Partners as an advisor to the biopharma industry.

He earned an MBA with honors from The Wharton School, where he majored in health care management and finance, as well as a degree in biological basis of behavior from the University of Pennsylvania.

acf.name: Dr. Patrick
acf.payoff: Proteins are my passion and dissecting their biophysics with such a talented team is a joy every day.
acf.text:
Patrick is a highly experienced biophysicist, protein engineer and project manager with substantial experience in the pharmaceutical industry. His passion for proteins is the common thread of his career. His contributions in the field of stability engineering of single-domain antibodies and protein spectroscopy resulted in eight peer-reviewed and highly cited publications and led him into the formulation development of biologics. As a project manager at the Coriolis Pharma Research GmbH (2019-2021), he led large formulation development projects and substantially accelerated the development of several different therapeutic entities together with small and big pharma companies. The resulting reputation made him responsible for the most challenging projects with the most difficult and complex molecules.

The basis for his work is his training in Molecular Biotechnology, Structural Biology and Biophysics, obtained at the University of Heidelberg (BSc 2007) and the ETH Zurich (MSc 2009). He had extended research stays at the Max-Planck-Institute for Medical Research and the MRC LMB in Cambridge focusing on protein folding and protein engineering. He obtained his PhD at the German Cancer Research Center (2017) for his work on antibody engineering and left academia after a PostDoc at the DKFZ in Heidelberg.

Patrick held several fellowships, including a research fellowship for his PhD from the Helmholtz International Graduate School, an excellence studentship from the Cusanuswerk (Bischöfliche Studienförderung) and a study abroad scholarship from the Cusanuswerk. He contributed to the textbook “Single-Domain Antibodies: Methods and Protocols” (Springer Science and Business Media 2022) and gave talks at various international conferences.

acf.name: Dr. George
acf.payoff: My family tells me that I sound happiest when I call home while on a photography trip. I know that this is true, but not exactly why it is true.
acf.text:
Dr. George Golumbeski has over 30 years of experience in the pharmaceutical and biotechnology industry. He is currently focused on new company creation and new company building. He is working on these objectives as a partner at DROIA Ventures where he focuses on “NewCos” dedicated to therapies for genetically defined diseases. He also serves as a Director for Sage Therapeutics, Vice Chair for MorphoSys, and Chair of the Board for Carrick Therapeutics and Shattuck Labs.

For nearly a decade, George was Executive Vice President of Business Development for Celgene where he was responsible for the full array of business development including in-licensing, strategic collaborations, M&A, out-licensing, and alliance management.

His fundamental mission at Celgene was to forge collaborations with biotechnology companies seeking to bring breakthrough medications to people suffering from cancer and chronic inflammation. To realize this goal, George developed new models for corporate collaborations, and led a business development effort that saw Celgene become “Partner of Choice” according to Boston Consulting Group Survey data.

Prior to Celgene, George was Vice President of Business Development, Licensing and Strategy at Novartis. Prior to Novartis, he was Vice President of R&D Business Development at Elan and Vice President of Corporate Development at Schwarz Pharma, where he led CNS acquisitions worldwide.

George holds a B.A. in Biology from the University of Virginia, a Ph.D. in Genetics from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and he conducted his post-doctoral research in molecular biology at the University of Colorado-Boulder.

Finally, George is committed to conservation; therefore, he serves on the Board of Directors of the National Audubon Society, and he is an avid nature photographer.

acf.name: Dr. Kamil
acf.payoff: Intrinsically Disordered Proteins are absolutely fascinating and now is the high time to unravel more of their mysteries.
acf.text:
Dr. Kamil Tamiola is a physicist turned entrepreneur. Fascinated by pioneering works of late Prof. Herman Berendsen (University of Groningen in the Netherlands) in the field of molecular dynamics and biomolecular simulations, Kamil decided to pursue an academic career in applied physics and biotechnology.

Yet, it was the bewildering behavior of an exotic class of intrinsically disordered proteins (IDPs) described in seminal works of Prof. Christopher Dobson of Cambridge that brought Kamil’s focus to nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (NMR) and a rapidly emerging field of IDPs.

Besides having a PhD degree in biomolecular sciences and applied physics, Kamil has turned his passion for photography and high altitude mountaineering into a professional activity working as a contributing photographer for National Geographic Benelux, Outdoor Photographer Magazine, Climbing Magazine and shooting commercial campaigns for outdoor brands including Rab, LowePro and others.

Kamil’s free time is split between mountains and grand piano practice, a remnant of his undergraduate piano conservatory education.

acf.name: Hussein
acf.payoff: We practice a simple craft. We have no scout program, no diversity fund, no founder collective, no secondary fund and no late-stage growth equity fund. Our focus is narrow — we find and help Europe’s best technology startups grow into large, dominant category-defining companies by investing in them in their earliest days. What we do may seem hard, but it is never harder than the entrepreneur’s journey.
acf.text:
Hussein is a partner at Hoxton Ventures. He currently represents Hoxton on the boards of Biotx, Finesse, Fy!, Giraffe360, Kbox, Peptone, Raptor Supplies, Skin Analytics, SOC.OS, TourRadar, XYZ Reality and Yieldify, and serves as a board observer on Behavox, Karakuri, Loveshark, Panakeia and Vidya Health. He previously served on the boards of Babylon Health, bd4travel (acquired by Dnata), Campanja (acquired by 24/7 Media), Darktrace and Deliveroo.

Hussein also serves on the board of Tech Nation. He also sits on the advisory board of GTO Partners, a tech mid-market buyout firm, and Landscape, a venture capital review site.

While forming Hoxton, he helped Eros STX Global develop ErosNow, an online streaming video platform for Bollywood. Prior to Hoxton, Hussein was an associate with Accel Partners. He joined Accel from Microsoft Corporation. Earlier in his career, he worked with three startups, Safe-View (acquired by L-3), Radiance Technologies (acquired by Comcast) and Studio Verso (acquired by KPMG).

Hussein holds an MBA from London Business School and did his undergraduate studies in Symbolic Systems at Stanford University. He stubbornly refuses to swear allegiance to a monarch and remains a proud American.

acf.name: Carlo
acf.payoff: My major interest is the scalability and the reliability of AI techniques in BigData frameworks that is AIOps.
acf.text:
I was born in Verbania, Italy, in 1992. I obtained a Bachelor’s degree in Physics in 2015, followed by a Master’s degree in Physics of Complex Systems in 2017 from the University of Turin. I also spent some time at the ISI Data Science Institute in Turin where I developed an AI and Quantum Computing-based tool for Natural Language Processing tasks.

In 2018, I started working at Moviri in Milan as a Data Scientist, becoming the Senior Data Scientist in 2020, Head of Modelling and AI activities.

In 2021, I became Chief Technology Officer at Peptone, developing technical aspects of the company’s strategy to ensure alignment with its business goals, discovering and implementing new technologies that yield competitive advantage.

I am keen on revolutionising the way Physical-Mathematical modelling and AI, Quantum Computing & High-Performance Computing can deliver business solutions for the pharma and biotech industry at scale.

acf.name: Dr. Rudy
acf.payoff: I love proteins and engineering them is my passion.
acf.text:
After working with enzymes during my early career, curiosity towards the development of innovative therapeutics is what brought me in contact with Peptone.
I obtained my MSc in Industrial Biotechnology from the University of Padua, Italy, applying rational design for biocatalytic applications. I then moved to the University of Groningen in The Netherlands for my PhD studies. My research was focused on the development of in vivo selections for the directed evolution of enzymes.

acf.name: Dr. Flavia
acf.text:
She obtained a master’s in Chemistry and Pharmaceutical Technology at “Sapienza”, University of Rome and a PhD in Biochemistry.

During her PhD, she mainly focused on the screening of natural compounds as modulators of disulfide isomerase activity. She moved to the University of Padua to join the molecular biology laboratory to develop a new split-GFP-based contact site sensor (SPLICS) to detect organelle interaction mainly focused on mitochondrial activity.

Finally, she joined a group of Experimental therapeutics at the Institute of Oncology Research in Bellinzona, where she focused on testing new strategies to modulate mitochondrial activity in hepatocellular carcinoma.

acf.name: Marta
acf.text:
Marta Fiocco is an HR and recruitment professional with over 8 years of experience in the field. With an educational foundation from the Lugano Business School, where she studied human resources, she has developed a comprehensive understanding of human resources and recruitment. 

What sets Marta apart is her international experience. She has had the opportunity to live and work in several countries across Asia and Europe, gaining a deep understanding of different cultures, work environments, and practices. This global exposure has enhanced her ability to adapt to diverse settings and communicate effectively with individuals from various backgrounds.

In addition to her professional achievements, Marta is passionate about continuous learning and staying abreast of industry trends. She actively participates in workshops, conferences, and networking events to expand her knowledge and skills in the field.

Outside of work, Marta enjoys exploring new destinations, immersing herself in different cultures, and embracing the culinary delights each country has to offer. She also finds joy in engaging in outdoor activities, such as hiking and cycling, which allow her to appreciate the beauty of nature and capture memorable moments.

acf.name: Dr. Michael
acf.text:
I received my undergraduate training in Biological Sciences at Konstanz University (BSc 2008, MSc 2011), focusing on molecular genetics, cell biology, and membrane protein biophysics. 

I then moved to the Weizmann Institute of Science where I obtained my PhD working on the characterization of protein-lipid- interactions. In particular how phospholipids and cholesterol affect Na,K-ATPase stability and activity using a combination of steady-state and time-resolved spectrophotometric assays, native mass spectrometry and activity assays.

In 2017 I joined Aarhus University to continue my work on Na,K-ATPase now with a focus on determining structures of isoforms by single-particle cryo-EM.

Over the years I gained a passion for working with challenging proteins and using a diverse and creative skillset for their characterisation.

acf.name: Heidi
acf.text:
Heidi Derks, a seasoned scientist specialising in Antibody Pharmacology and Bioassays, has accumulated valuable industry experience through roles at MSD, GlaxoSmithKline, Synthon, and the Singapore Immunology Network. Known for her hands-on approach, Heidi combines technical expertise with a genuine passion for drug development. Her commitment to precision is evident in her meticulous work ethic, consistently aiming to deliver robust, high-quality results.

In the lab, Heidi focuses on (Bio)assay development, qualification, and automation, showcasing a versatile skill set encompassing various techniques, from HTRF to imaging and 3D cell cultures.

Beyond her scientific contributions, she enjoys creating a collaborative atmosphere within the team. She is a dedicated professional, committed to Peptone’s mission with precision and passion.

Outside of work, she maintains an active lifestyle and enjoys hiking, running and snowboarding.

acf.name: Dr. Michele
acf.text:
After obtaining a bachelor’s and master’s in physics at the University of Milan, I moved to Switzerland, where I earned my PhD in computational physics at ETH Zurich under the supervision of prof Michele Parrinello. My main focus was developing novel enhanced sampling methods to extend the scope of molecular dynamics simulations.

I later moved to Berlin for a postdoc in Artificial Intelligence for the Sciences in the group of prof Frank Noé. There, I studied generative models based on deep artificial neural networks, such as normalizing flows and diffusion models.

My main application remained atomistic simulations of physical systems, from condensed matter to biomolecules.

acf.name: Dr. Nathalie
acf.payoff: I am fascinated by the dynamic nature of proteins and use biophysical methods to unravel their kinetic binding landscape.
acf.text:
I have an MSc in Biochemistry from the University of Zurich, focusing on the dynamics and kinetics of intrinsically disordered proteins studied by single-molecule FRET

After my degree, I obtained an industrial PhD from Novo Nordisk A/S and the University of Aarhus, Denmark.

In my project I focused on avidity and multivalent target engagement of antibodies using a variety of different biophysical and structural characterization methods, including SPR and electron microscopy.

acf.name: Dr. Lawrence
acf.payoff: Dr. Lawrence Steinman is a professor of Neurology and Neurological Sciences, Pediatrics, and Genetics.
acf.text:
Dr. Steinman’s research focuses on what provokes relapses and remission in multiple sclerosis (MS), the nature of the molecules that serve as a brake on the brain inflmmation, and the quest for a tolerizing vaccine for autoimmune diseases like type 1 diabetes and neuromyelitis optica.  He has developed two antigen specific therapies, using DNA vaccines, for MS and type 1 diabetes.  He was senior author on the seminal 1992 Nature article that reported the key role of a particular integrin in brain inflammation.  This research led to the development of the drug Tysabri, which is used to treat patients with MS and Crohn’s disease.

Dr. Steinman received his BA from Dartmouth College and his MD from Harvard University. He was a post-doctoral fellow in chemical immunology fellow at the Weizmann Institute of Science in Israel. Dr. Steinman returned to Stanford University Hospital as a resident in pediatric and adult neurology and then joined the faculty at Stanford in 1980.

Dr. Steinman has received numerous honors and awards, including the John M. Dystel Prize from the American Academy of Neurology and the National MS Society for his research on MS, and the Charcot Prize for Lifetime Achievement in MS research. He has twice been awarded the Senator Jacob Javits Neuroscience Investigator Award by the National Institute of Neurological Diseases and Stroke. Dr. Steinman is a member of the National Academy of Sciences and the National Academy of Medicine, formerly called the Institute of Medicine.

Dr. Steinman holds a number of patents in the areas of immunology, and for therapies of Huntington Disease, type 1 diabetes and MS. He cofounded Neurocrine Biosciences, Bayhill Therapeutics now named Tolerion, Nuon Therapeutics, Transparency Life Sciences and Atreca.
